YO1 Festival Food - The Review

06/05/2014

Sunaina Suri samples the food and drink on offer at last weekend's YO1 festival

Image by

By undefined undefined

This year's YO1 was packed with groovy tunes, proper craft ales and cloudy skies. I was looking forward to the food just as much as the music, and I wasn't let down. Ranging from festival-esque dirty double cheeseburgers to vegetarian paellas, there really was something for everyone. When I arrived at the festival, before getting a pint of ale from the House of Trembling Madness craft beer festival, I went straight to Piggy Smalls. They were serving up pulled pork subs with homemade slaw and sticky Jack Daniels BBQ sauce. You were even presented with a choice of chutney made from chilli peppers, or spicy chipotle sauce. The sub was so tender and flavourful that I avoided drinking my pint for a while so that I could savour the pork. The chutney was sweet and spicy, making it suitable for most palates.                   Continuing with the pulled pork trend, Diamond Dogs served up 'The Boss Dog' which had BBQ pulled pork, chipotle mustard, pink onions, pickles all topped off with BBQ sauce. They also had standard hot dogs, chilli cheese dogs and 'The Black Dog' which was a Mexican addition to their menu.                                             Another option for meat lovers was the meatball sub by Pig & Pastry, one of their signature savoury dishes. They also had a stall packed with desserts - almond cakes, brownies, lollipops, flapjacks and coffee. Another establishment of this type was Heslington Road's Bison Coffee, serving a variety of toasties, coffee and their much-loved brownies. Being a local fixture and having attended last year's YO1, Bison were a familiar face. The scrumptious food didn't end there though. Las Paelleras served up amazing paella dishes. To quote Ellie Wright, a third year English Literature student, "This is the best festival food I have ever had." While she had a spicy vegetarian option, I had the milder chicken and chorizo paella. Served with green beans, it was a well-rounded dish that was cooked to perfection, particularly considering it was made fresh on site.                                                 Some other highlights were the pizzas from Streatza (there was a long wait but the freshness made it worth it), Jamaican food - curried goat and jerk chicken wraps? Yes please!. Shambles Kitchen, also made an appearance, serving kebabs packed with spices, sauces and vegetables.                                         Fish& was back this year and everyone seemed to enjoy it. They had more items on their menu than most stalls and the food was just as good as I remember from last year. Their original lemon and chilli fish is definitely worth trying.                                           The main vegetarian option was Chaat Cart, run by a couple based in Manchester. Serving up dishes such as samosa chaat, it brought me back to times when my mother would buy food for me from roadside stalls in India. That is definitely a testament to how good the food was. The highlight for most people (from the rumblings I could hear among the crowd) was Cowboy Burgers. Their double burger, 'The Dirty Double', attracted people to come back for seconds and even thirds. Made fresh with a moist patty in between soft brioche rolls, it was everything you wanted a burger to be. On the sweet side of things, the ice cream from York-based Swirlz was amazing. Had it been a sunny day, I probably would have eaten at least five cones. Another sweet treat was the Apple Pie cocktail from Speakeasy cocktails. It was sweet and cooling - perfect after watching De La Soul's dance-filled set. I was craving a crepe to go with the many other desserts I had but I couldn't find Crepe Lucette amongst the stalls.                         YO1 doesn't ever skimp on the food & beverage front. With a price range of PS4-7, they may not feature the cheapest grub available, but it is a great introduction to local and freshly prepared, honest food. If you missed out on YO1 this year (or if this article has made you hungry), be sure to check out the featured food outlets dotted around the North - they won't disappoint.
